abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy Sector Deregulation and
            Privatization Project's outcome was rate
            unsatisfactory. The support for both an independent
            regulatory system and privatization proved to be weak, and
            the government did not live up to its commitment. Some key
            lessons include: 1) Build-own-operates and independent power
            producers can be a useful vehicle to mobilize additional
            resources for the electricity sector and shift the
            construction and technical performance risks to private
            investors. However, structuring them may require a lot of
            time and senior management attention, and involve numerous
            agreements, which is one reason why they are not necessarily
            at a low-cost solution. 2) In an electricity system that
            depends on the supply by private firms, this private failure
            can become a public problem. It is therefore necessary for
            the Bank to pay attention to the technical aspects of such
            projects. 3) In lending to privately owned utilities, the
            Bank should avoid creating a new financial window which
            might end up being used for only one transaction or a very
            small number of transactions. 4) Care should be exercised in
            undertaking Operation Evaluation Department performance
            audit reports prior to the implementation completion report.
            5) While a comprehensive and innovative approach to sector
            development has obvious attractions, it may exceed the
            country's implemntation capacity. It may also require
            more supervision resources than the Bank is prepared to allocate.
